channel.title: KenSmith tweets
channel.description: A feed of recent tweets from KenSmith.

item.description: Last night: Fox ‚Äúnews‚Äù people rebutting a report they hadn‚Äôt seen yet as it was being broadcast live on the other channels. https://t.co/0fIFFAGbqz

Not just hearing music any time. Exploring music, and choosing the explorer‚Äôs path for oneself, and moment by moment calling the tune for one‚Äôs own life. A thing never seen before. https://t.co/MG73EYWL3W
Alternative narrative already underway on that one channel now. https://t.co/mTCaxUYRJT
Publish this list as soon as possible. https://t.co/KMxDwxd83M
Web3: " I honestly don't think such a thing exists." Brief thread. https://t.co/iyYYs6vYFP

Odd @NPR lingo thing these days: using present tense verbs to describe past events. Here, the reporter asks questions about past actions using present tense verbs even when the interviewee speaks of her past life with past tense verbs. Weird tic, @NPR. https://t.co/Qelwxz7yTP
‚ÄúWe made the world we‚Äôre living in and we have to make it over,‚Äù said James Baldwin. https://t.co/1qq61Ly6TT

‚ÄúTo change peoples‚Äô minds about guns, we must give them reason to trust. This means investing in public systems that give people cause to believe that they will be appropriately protected so they might loosen their defensive grip on guns and embrace gun laws that protect us all.‚Äù https://t.co/SL6qrH1dQw https://t.co/slx9QqFxeR
I read and reread the tweet in question a couple weeks ago and couldn‚Äôt discover what could possibly have triggered the content warning from @Twitter. So I appealed. https://t.co/ZwUkVibekD

Journalists on air tend to emphasize the first syllable, saying ‚ÄúPROUDboys‚Äù and making it sound like it‚Äôs bursting out of loudspeakers at a rally. Slow down, just say ‚Äú. . . the group that calls itself . . the . . proud . . boys.‚Äù

‚ÄúIt just exacerbates all the conspiratorial stuff that we have swirling around and sets us on a dangerous course. It further corrodes our ability to be grounded in the same empirical reality.‚Äù ‚ÄîWhitney Phillips / @WPhillips49 https://t.co/Vjb0deb0ZO

One excellent thing about the @RuralWriting Institute is that it suggests a model for developing and celebrating writing from any less-heard-from groups and places in society. @herdyshepherd1 @theshepherdswi1 @kathrynaalto https://t.co/5reY46PPCo

‚ÄúAt the end of the talk, of which I understood frustratingly little, Derrida asked a question that took about 20 minutes to formulate. Laclau‚Äôs response was of equal length.‚Äù The question from the title is maybe answered behind the PAYWALL. https://t.co/Sx5xAhkM52
Good to see @TeenVogue planting the idea among young readers that environmental emergencies can largely be the result of human activity. https://t.co/MlrJxWQpTh

"While the Dust Bowl, a largely man-made environmental emergency, lays bare the destruction humans can wreak on the environment, it also shows how large-scale collective response can help mitigate environmental disaster . . ." https://t.co/prRQjPN0Ke

I'm very fond of this entire poster. I wish we could add a pithy line or two at the bottom that indicated that these worthy and essential bundles of knowledge-attitudes-skills only give citizens much of a chance of success if they know how to . . . 1/2 https://t.co/EKh833heuA
. . . how to affiliate with others, amplify the voices of others, and defend institutions from being hollowed out, how to make the powerful take notice of the reach and staying power in citizens' voices because citizens have done the work to build public voices of that kind. 2/2
Sadly, it‚Äôs endlessly reusable cover art. https://t.co/E2Okuo4glf

‚ÄúThere is an inherent conflict in asking people to change their most personal habits because of climate change when government policy puts few restraints on polluting industries like oil, gas, coal and automobiles.‚Äù ‚ÄîAnnaliese Griffin https://t.co/fLKcrGMb9T

As the story goes, a family friend, when she was maybe ten, saw Fr. Hesburgh on the @NotreDame campus, approached him and said, ‚ÄúFather, thank you for making Notre Dame co-ed,‚Äù and he replied, ‚ÄúSomebody had to do it. It was like a locker room around this place.‚Äù
@davewiner I‚Äôm guessing you gather information for three rows, then solve.
‚ÄúA book must be the axe for the frozen sea within us. That is my belief.‚Äù Franz Kafka https://t.co/uDGsxOAaY8
Adding more and more guns . . . A piece by @SkinnerPm. https://t.co/g2D6Oec5Ye https://t.co/A4fugasafE
The pond is all lawyered up. https://t.co/UVPsrlPljS

Wordle 349 3/6 ‚¨õüü®‚¨õüü®‚¨õ üü®üü®üü©‚¨õüü© üü©üü©üü©üü©üü© 1. First word has five of the top nine letters for frequency in English: etaonrish. 2. If that yields two yellows, second word should move those letters and include another three from the top nine.

Got elected to public office? Need a form letter to give voters the feeling that their voices might matter but maybe not? Rip off the bones of this model and start a-mailing . . . https://t.co/7m2nncWApJ
